description:
Xerus inauris, commonly known as the Cape ground squirrel, is a species of ground squirrel native to southern Africa. It belongs to the genus Xerus, which includes several species of African ground squirrels.

The Cape ground squirrel is a medium-sized rodent with a body length of approximately 20-30 cm and a bushy tail that is slightly shorter than the body. It has a distinctive grayish-brown fur with lighter underparts and a dark stripe along the sides of the body. The species is known for its social behavior, living in colonies and exhibiting complex communication and foraging strategies.

These ground squirrels are well-adapted to their arid and semi-arid environments, with physiological and behavioral adaptations that allow them to thrive in the hot, dry conditions of their native range. They are primarily herbivorous, feeding on a variety of plant materials, including seeds, nuts, and green vegetation.

The Cape ground squirrel plays an important role in the ecosystem as a prey species, contributing to the food web and serving as a source of food for various predators. It also contributes to the dispersal of plant seeds, contributing to the regeneration of the vegetation in its habitat.
